p: A proportion of influenza virus particles have defective genome RNAs (DVGs) due to internal deletions of viral segments [ 11– 14]. The DVGs have the 3’ and 5’ ends of the parental RNA segments, and most have a single, large central deletion that generates viral RNAs of 180–1000 nucleotides [ 15– 17]. DVGs have been found for all viral segments, but most derive from PB2, PB1 and PA RNAs [ 15, 17, 18]. The presence of DVGs potentiates the host response in cultured cells [ 19, 20] and in animal models and leads to attenuated infection [ 21], possibly through recognition of double-stranded RNA by receptors that activate antiviral signaling cascades [ 19] (reviewed in [ 22]).
